resources.text: Primitives are the most basic types of variables that we can use. In this chapter we will go through all of them to see how they work and what they can be used for.
resources.boxed: In a later course we will see how creating classes allows us to write useful methods for out data types. Primitives are not classes however, they can't have methods! To counter this, wrapper classes are provided. They "wrap" a primitive type into a class, and give us access to utility methods.
resources.text:
We already know the int primitive. It's a numeric type to store signed integers.

Wrapper: The wrapper class of the int primitive is Integer.

Range: 32 bits are used to store an int, and so they can have a minimum value of -2^31 and a maximum value of 2^31-1. These values are stored as constants of the wrapper class:
resources.code:
int min = Integer.MIN_VALUE;
int max = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
resources.text: Default value: The default value of an int is 0.
resources.advanced:
You may wonder what happens when we add 1 to an int which has maximum value. An intuitive answer is that it won't grow any more, but this isn't the case. Instead, it overflows, and becomes the smallest possible value.

You can read more about this on it's Wikipedia article

The following numeric types also exhibit this behaviour, with their respective minimum and maximum values.
resources.text:
Long is another numeric type. It can be used when we wish to work with values so big, that they are outside the range of int.

Wrapper: The wrapper class of the long primitive is Long.

Range: 64 bits are used to store a long. It can have a minimum value of -2^63 and a maximum value of 2^63-1. Just like with int, you can get the these bounds as wrapper class constants.

Default value: The default value of a long is 0.
resources.code:
long big = Integer.MAX_VALUE * 2;
long l1 = 1418284149L;
resources.text:
As an example, and a demonstration that the long type has a wider range, we can see that this variable has the value of twice the upper bound of an int, and still, it won't overflow.

The second example shows that the l or L characters can be used at the end of declaration to emphasise that we declared a long. Note that this is optional.

More numeric types. Their range is smaller then int, so they use less memory. They are rarely used, since nowadays our computers have access to an excess amount of memory.

Wrapper: The wrapper classes are Byte and Short.

Range: 8 bits for byte and 16 bits for short. This leaves the bounds at [-128,127] for byte and [-32768,32767] for short.

Default value: 0 for both types.

Yet another numeric type, but unlike the previous ones, this can store real numbers, not just integers.

Wrapper: The wrapper class is Double.

Range: Their range is far greater then any previous types, and for almost all applications, you can assume it's boundless.

Default value: 0.0
resources.code:
double d1 = 3.65;
double d2 = -21.941743242;
//Don't need to write 423.0, but we can
double d3 = 423;

double res = d1 + d2;
resources.text: Observe the above examples to see that a dot is used to declare doubles. Arithmetic can also be performed on them.

A primitive to store real numbers, but it has a smaller range then double, and thus uses less memory. It's rarely used, for the same reason as byte and short.

Wrapper: The wrapper class is Float.

Default value: 0f
It's declared similarly as a double, but notice the f at the end. It must be used to tell the compiler we are declaring a float.

Our first non numeric primitive type. It can only have two possible values, true and false.

Wrapper: The wrapper class is Boolean.

Default value: false
resources.code:
int i1 = 1, i2 = 2;
boolean b1 = i1 > 7; //false
boolean b2 = i2 <= 1; //true
boolean b3 = i2 == 3; //false
boolean b4 = i1 != i2; //true
resources.text:
As you can see, additional comparison operators are at our disposal when using booleans. They can compare other (mostly numeric) primitives. The comparison is either true of false, so the result can be assigned to a boolean.

These are pretty straightforward, the only ones that may need explanation are <= and >= (greater-or-equal, less-or-equal), and != (not equal).
resources.code:
boolean b = true;
b = !b; //b will be false
resources.text:
This example illustrates the negate operator. You can use it on a boolean to quickly "swap" it's value.

We can also use the AND, OR and XOR logical operators on booleans:
resources.list:
• AND (a && b): Will only result in true of both a and b are true.
  • AND (a || b): Will only result in true of either a or b are true.
  • XOR (a ^ b): Will only result in true of either a or b, but not both are true.
resources.code:
boolean a = true, b = false;
boolean c = a && b; //false
c = a || b; //true
c = a ^ b; //true

resources.text:
The last primitive, it's used to represent unicode characters. It's got 16 bits to store the integer representation of the unicode characters.

Wrapper: The wrapper class is Character.

Default value: '\u0000'
resources.code:
char c1 = '\u0011';
char c2 = 'A';
char c3 = 'Ã¤';
resources.text: As you can see, we must always put the declared character between apostrophes, but we aren't required to use the unicode integer codes, it's enough to simply place any character there.
resources.boxed:
We have already seen the String class. We use quotation marks to declare them, and they aren't primitives. A char is not a String with only one character!

Despite this, Java allows us to use them together in certain situations.
resources.code:
String s = "mam";
char aChar = 'a';
s = s + aChar;
//will print mama
System.out.println(s);
resources.text: Notice that the + operator that is used to "join" two strings together is now used on a String and a char.

interactive.instruction: Declare a character variable with value 'C'!

resources.text: A primitive type is not the same as its wrapper class, however, they can be interchanged in the code. The compiler will do the necessary conversions. This is called autoboxing.
resources.code:
static void printChar(char c) {
    System.out.println(c);
}
resources.text: This method takes a char primitive, but passing a Character (wrapper) variable is also fine:
resources.code:
printChar('a'); //with primitive
printChar(new Character('b')); //with wrapper
printChar(Character.valueOf('c')); //with wrapper
resources.text: This is going to be especially useful when using generics (covered in a later course).
